_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: State of Alaska CAA Title V Operating Permit

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Central Gas Facility (CGF) is classified as NAICS code 211111, Crude Petroleum and Natural Gas Production.  A Program 1 plan for both the propane refrigeration process and NGL/MI process is being submitted.



Description of  stationary source and regulated substances handled



CGF is designed to improve overall field gas off-take by recovering natural gas liquids (NGL) and miscible injectant (MI) from the gas and then (together with the Central Compressor Plant [CCP]) compress and return the remaining residue gas into the gas cap of the Prudhoe Bay reservoir.  The NGL and MI products are captured from the feed gas stream using a refrigeration/condensation process.  Current production is approximately 60,000 barrels per day of NGL with a portion of that production shipped to Kuparuk oil field for MI injection.  The remaining NGL production is blended with crude oil and sent to Pump Station 1 (operated by Alyeska Pipeline Service Company).  Approximately 350 million standard cubic feet per day (MMscfd) of MI product is produced for use in the Prudhoe Bay oil field.  When compressed and re-injected into the oil bearing formation, MI lowers the viscosity of the crude oil, allowing it to flow to the well bore more easily.  The overall effect is a significant increase in recoverable oil.  



Propane Refrigeration and Manufacturing System



o CGF utilizes propane in a refrigeration system.  The propane refrigeration system is a closed circulating loop.  Liquid propane is generally manufactured at CGF, stored in the 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum and added as make-up to the 19-1216 surge drum as needed.  The propane refrigerant system includes the following equipment and approximate inventories:



o The 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum provides liquid propane storage for make-up. The storage drum has a design liquid volume of approximately 124,351 gallons (2,961 bbl) @ 4.23 lbs/gal = 525,888 lbs.



o The 19-1216 refrigerant surge drum provides liquid propane sto

rage. The surge drum contains approximately 32,050 gallons (763 bbl)@ 4.2 lbs/gal = 134,610 lbs.



An economizer system facilitates compression of propane refrigerant in multiple stages, which improves overall system efficiency: 

o The LP economizer has a design liquid volume of approximately 12,100 gallons (288 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 50,820 lbs.

o The HP economizer has a design liquid volume of approximately 15,290 gallons (364 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 64,220 lbs.

o Four chillers (19-1310, 19-1360, 19-1386-A and 19-1386-B) allow for heat exchange between incoming process natural gas and propane refrigerant. The total design volume for all four chillers is approximately 64,880 gallons (1,540 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 271,660 lbs.

o The LP Suction Drums (19-1211 and 19-1261) are for final liquids gravitational separation from gaseous propane before compression.  The Suction Drums have a total design liquid volume of approximately 12,520 gallons (298 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 52,580 lbs.

o The De-ethanizer and De-propanizer equipment in the propane manufacturing process have a combined design liquid volume of approximately 1,722 gallons (41 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 7,230 lbs.



Additional propane volume is found in the system through the associated process piping.  This additional volume is estimated to be 60% of the total vessel volume (259,700 gallons), which is approximately 155,820 gallons (3,710 bbl) @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 654,445 lbs.



Total propane inventory onsite is approximately 416,417 gallons (9,914 bbl) @ 4.23 lb/gal = 1,761,443 lbs.



The refrigerant storage drum is located along the West edge of the CGF facility pad, slightly North of center.  This orientation provides for better potential dispersion from bimodal Southwest/Northeast winds.



Catastrophic loss of inventory of the 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum and subsequent vapor cloud explosion (VCE) to the 1 psi endpoint is the basis for the Worst Case Scenario calculations.  The model used was a TNT Equivalent Cal

culation in RMP*Comp.



Gas Handling/Gas Injection and Stabilization Processes



Natural gas is routed to low-temperature processing where it is chilled using the propane refrigeration process to extract NGLs for use as MI.  The mixed NGL, comprised primarily of liquid hydrocarbons in propane (C3) through pentane (C5) range, is a regulated flammable substance.  The quantity of NGL/MI stored and in process at CGF consists of the following equipment and approximate inventories:



Gas Handling/ Gas Injection Process

o The Inlet Separator 19-1237 has a design liquid volume of 6,175 gallons (147 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 19,420 lbs.

o The Portatest has a design liquid volume of 760 gallons (18 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 2,390 lbs.

o Both LT Separators, 19-1101 & 19-1151, have a design liquid volume of 41,370 gallons (985 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 130,100 lbs. each.

o Both LTS Reboilers, 19-1308  & 19-1358, have a design liquid volume of 12,050 gallons (287 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 37,900 lbs. each.

o Each of the four LP Suction Scrubbers, 19-1288, 19-1290, 19-1292, & 19-1294, has a design liquid volume of 1,470 gallons (35 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 4,625 lbs. each.

o Each of the four HP Suction Scrubbers, 19-1289, 19-1291, 19-1293 & 19-1295, has a design liquid volume of 588 gallons (14 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 1,850 lbs. each



Additional NGL/MI volume is available in the system through the associated process piping.  This additional volume for the Gas Handling/ Gas Injection Process portion of the NGL/MI Process is estimated to be 60% of the total vessel volume (122,007 gallons), which is approximately 73,205 gallons

(1,743 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 230,205 lbs.



The total NGL/MI in the Gas Handling/ Gas Injection Process is approximately 195,210 gallons (4,648 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 613,880 lbs.



Stabilization Process

o Both Stabilizers, 19-1102 & 19-1152, have a design liquid volume of 7,435 gallons (177 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 23,380 lbs. each.

o Both Stabilizers Reboilers, 19-1315 & 19-1365, have a design liquid volume of 17,900 gallons (426 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 56,290 lbs. each.

o The Stabilizer Overhead Drum 19-1206 has a design liquid volume of 12,010 gallons (286 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 37,765 lbs.

o Both LP Suction Scrubbers, 19-1207 & 19-1257, have a design liquid volume of 1,555 gallons (37 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 4,890 lbs. each.

o Both Blowcases, 19-1208  & 19-1258, have a design liquid volume of 715 gallons (17 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 2,250 lbs. each.

o The NGL Divert Tank 19-1233 has a design liquid volume of 63,340 gallons (1,508 bbl) of NGL/MI @ 5.33 lb/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 199,185 lbs.



Additional NGL/MI volume is available in the system through the associated process piping.  This additional volume for the Stabilization Process portion of the NGL/MI Process is estimated to be 60% of the total vessel volume (130,560 gallons), which is approximately 78,335 gallons (1,865 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 204,590 lbs.



The total NGL/MI in the Stabilization Process is approximately 208,900 gallons (4,973 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5)

= 656,930 lbs.



The total NGL/MI onsite inventory (combined Gas Handling/Gas Injection and Stabilization Processes) is approximately 404,110 gallons (9,622 bbl) @ 5.33 lbs/gal and 59% by weight Part 68 subject components (C1-C5) = 1,270,805 lbs.



Catastrophic loss of inventory of the NGL Divert Tank 19-1233 and subsequent vapor cloud explosion (VCE) to the 1 psi endpoint is the basis for the Worst Case Scenario calculations for the NGL/MI processes. The model used was a TNT Equivalent Calculation in RMP*Comp.



Other Information Required Per 40 CFR 68.155:



CGF's accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are predicated on compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps include process hazard analysis (PHA) and layer of protection analysis (LOPA).  The facility has had no accidents in the past five years from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  The emergency response program was developed consistent with OSHA's Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) and PSM standards, as well as other applicable regulations.  Planned changes to improve safety occur through the OSHA VPP process. 



Enclosed modules which house process equipment operated at CGF are equipped with fire suppression systems.  In the event of fire, HalonA1 fire suppressant is automatically released to inhibit the chemical reaction of combustion and extinguish the flames.  



Prudhoe Bay has its own professionally-trained fire department which responds and serves as the local fire department.  There is no other jurisdiction providing emergency response at CGF, with the exception of mutual aid provided by the fire departments of other nearby North-Slope Alaska oil fields.
